title: Stixmentation - Probabilistic Stixel based Traffic Scene Labeling
segmentation: Hello everybody, my name is British apps and I'm from the image Understanding Group of Daimler.
It is a great honor for me to be given this opportunity to present our work in sticksel segmentation here.
This work has been done by me and my coauthors, the other shots and over Franca well.
The question we investigate in our contribution is to detect moving objects and to separate them from stationary background using a stereo camera system.
Consider this example.
Traffic seen here as I told you, we want to find the moving objects in a scene.
Besides that, we try to classify the driving maneuver.
So what is the object actually doing is I'm coming like this here or is it turning to the right?
Well, this step is crucial for many driver assistant systems and for autonomous driving applications which is our main field of interest.

In order to find the potential moving objects in a scene, and in order to infer the precision, we first have to recover the scene depth information using a stereo algorithm that I will introduce in the following.
We use the semi global matching algorithm to estimate the depth information for almost all pixels in the scene on this step is stereo computation step.
Here runs in real time on a special FDA platform.
However, this huge amount of data here is expensive to process for further algorithmic steps.
About half a million individual stereo measurements are too much for our applications.
Well, besides that, we still do not know the precision of the relevant objects in the scene.
There are large parts of the image like the street here which do not contain any relevant information.

Besides that, we would prefer a more robust scene representation that is insensitive to stereo measurement outliers, mainly due to these reasons, we turned to the so called pixel world that I will introduce in the following.
Here you see the sticks world, the sticker world conditions an input image into planar free space and into vertical obstacles.
Using the sticks world, it is possible to describe almost all the relevant depth information in a scene, using about 500 stickles instead of typically half a million individual stereo measurements.
However, the sticks world.
Just encodes the depth information in a scene.
In order to find the motion information, we have to track the sticks overtime and we end up with the so called dynamic sticksel world.
In order to find the motion information, retract testicles overtime using optical flow information and stereo information.
Here the errors shows show the predicted position of the stickless within the next half second.
We use common filtering to measure the auto infer the object velocities very precisely.
However, there are still several OK.

Besides that, for many applications, a grouping of the sticks into objects is desirable well, and that's the point where the sticks mentation comes into the game that I will introduce in the following.
This slide here is thought to be a short motivation slide to illustrate the complexity.
To find the moving objects.
We would like to infer emotion segmentation into uncoming traffic objects moving forward, objects turning right and stationary, background shown in black here.
This figure here shows the desired output of the segmentation step.
Let's assume that this problem has a simple solution.
Maybe it's sufficient to just threshold the observed velocities.
Let's see what is the outcome of this velocity thresholding.
Oops Mr result.
Do you like it?
I think it's pretty bad, as you can see the motion information alone is not sufficient for the segmentation step.
We have to do better.
Well, at this point I want to review some related works.
First, just beautiful and pioneering work done by Brostoff and by us in 2008 and 2009 in the field of scene labeling for the static scenes.
In 2010, Sun proposed a super pixel approach in their work.
They were just relying on dense depth information, inferred from structure from motion cues.
However, none of these approaches exploits motion information.
I think motion information is one of the most powerful cues for driver assistance systems.
Besides that, there are several approaches for dynamic scenes as well.
First, there's a pretty new publication by owner.
It is about a joint motion estimation and segmentation.
This is an unsupervised, continuous approach.
I think this is great work and they have very promising results.
However, our work differs in some aspects.
First we use super pixels instead of individual pixels.
We think or we found out, that this is more robust and it is possible to define more discriminative features on super pixels.
Besides that, of course, the computational burden is lower.
Instead of using or in their work, they just.
Used the optical flow feature.
We use multiple features which also increases the robustness.
Robustness in general is very important for applications because we have further error sources like Diego Motion estimation.
Besides that there are clustering based methods.
As this approach you I think the problem with this kind of approach is that they typically have difficulties with noisy data.
Finally, there was an approach and conditional random field approach by bot in 2010.
It is unseen flow segmentation approach using a conditional random field.
The problem with this approach was that it was not so robust.
We had problems with the dense optical flow and with Diego motion compensation.
And we found out that the regularization on the single pixel level was not sufficient in this case.
Well, for this reason, let's go back to the segmentation step.
As usual, we try to find the best segmentation innovation sense.
We have 5 object classes namely objects, moving forward objects, turning left or right on coming traffic and stationary background.
We formulate the segmentation task as the energy minimization of a conditional random field with unary terms and with binary terms.
Each pixel has a 5 dimensional input feature vector including a 2 dimensional velocity information, a 2 dimensional world position and a height measurement.

Here in about 1 millisecond on a single CPU core, and that's the reason why we can test our approach in real time in our experimental vehicle.
So let me conclude I've presented to you the sticks mentation the conditional random field approach for traffic scene labeling for dynamic scenes.
Using the sticks, a world lowest computational burden significantly and it increases the stability.
We were able to compute the Alex Pension Graph Scheme here in one millisecond.
Besides that, I've shown you some experimental results and I could demonstrate the performance of our approach and its ability to generalize to unseen traffic scenes.
So thank you very much for your attention if there are any questions, I would be happy to answer them.
